comments.commentBody: Sorry, comrade, but Russia is not our ally.

That was fun, and there ARNO regrets.
Edith.

Trump fans the flames every time he tweets. A more controlled individual would avoid this growing controversy, but Trump can't do that. And he couldn't do it during the campaign, either. Talking about the DNC hacking, he said he hoped that the Russians would continue and find Clinton's "30,000 deleted emails." By now, even a child wouldn't believe Trump's denials about his campaign's interaction with the Russians, even extending to Russian intelligence.

These trouble me deeply, but not as much as Trump's missing tax returns, which now must come to light, if necessary by subpoena. How much is his shaky fortune beholden to Russian money, and what influence could such debts or "investments" have over his foreign-policy decisions? That's the question that overrides them all.

“The president’s supporters say innocuous encounters, routine for any incoming presidential team, are being treated for political reasons as somehow subversive.”

No we are just asking why you keep lying about it. If its so innocuous why the lies?

It could be collusion with Russians, it could be creating the appearance of collusion to create this hubbub to distract folks from something else you guys are doing.
Well-researched and well-written piece. What happened to Thieu after the fall of Saigon?  Didn't he seek refuge in London on a flight with suitcases filled with American gold bullions?

Hi Viv.

Sorry, wasn't watching the time.

This is what we get for failing to be and raise adults for the past 40 years.
Let's hope a decent cohort of Millenials actually listened and learned a few things while recording YouTube interviews with their Great-Grandparents...
Dream on.

Please Richard explain how the world was "stable" before President Obama took office. Even if you meant to imply the Middle East was stable, that does not explain the cycle of violence that stemmed from Saddam Hussein's annexation of Kuwait nineteen years earlier. And have you forgotten the overthrow of the Shah? The oil embargo? The Arab-Israeli wars? The invasion of the Suez Canal?
I am afraid as our country's population ages, the tendency to see history through rose-colored spectacles is becoming endemic, and is an increasing barrier to making well informed decisions in the present.
This column, yes, but more generally all of Journalism defends the Constitution, which is journalism's true and rightful purpose.

The contempt runs both ways, the MSM, Hollywood & the democrats clearly have contempt for Trump. The MSM and Hollywood even read into the subliminal message behind the outfit that the FLOTUS wore; and it was rich that Hollywood was complaining about the price of the First Lady's dress immediately after the always ostentatious Academy Awards ceremony!

Fox News was no fan of Obama, but the level of vitriol was not the same as we are already seeing directed at Trump. Hollywood is in attack mode, something that Obama did not have to contend with all, just the opposite, Hollywood was 100% smitten.

The MSM is crying Chicken Little, and in doing so is compromising its credibility as a reliable news source, which a democracy truly needs.

No, you're not on the fence (or the wall!). You've drunk the Trump Kook-Aid! (Typo for Kool-Aid, but Kook-Aid may be more appropriate!)

He hasn't built that wall, by the way. His first immigration order was hastily drawn, blatantly anti-Muslim, and was blocked. It is clearly illegal. The deportations and ban are making the U.S. less safe, not more.

His NSA guy had to resign; his AG had to recuse himself; every day more comes out about improper Russian-Trump contacts. His approval ratings are in the tank-- as was his inauguration crowd! His tweets have become more and more unhinged-- he's back to being obsessed by Obama.

Analysts reported that the other day was the first time in months that he went a day without a clear lie-- but then went right back to it!

Sorry, but so far, the score is Trump -47 and the rule of law and people's rights, a 26.

Reporters do investigative reporting, Mr. Harrison. Opinion writers concentrate more on opinion.

And they are biased, often.

Don't know why you'd think that Charles Blow shouldn't have whoever he wants as close friends. (But I could guess why he hasn't responded to whatever you've written him.)

The contempt runs both ways, the MSM, Hollywood & the democrats clearly have contempt for Trump. The MSM invented a subliminal message behind the outfit that the FLOTUS wore; and it was rich that Hollywood was complaining about the price of the First Lady's dress immediately after the ostentatious-as-always Academy Awards ceremony! The MSM and Hollywood treated Michelle Obama with all the respect that she deserved, but not so much with the current FLOTUS.

Fox News was no fan of Obama, but the level of vitriol was not the same as we are already seeing directed at Trump by the MSM. Hollywood is in attack mode, something that Obama did not have to contend with at all, just the opposite, Hollywood was 100% smitten.

The MSM is crying Chicken Little, and in doing so is compromising its credibility as a reliable news source, which a democracy truly needs but really does not have, since the press is as polarized as the 2 political parties are.

People have contempt for Trump because he is a shameless, shallow, insipid fraud who seeks only self-enrichment. He lies incessantly, and his paranoia should be cause for great concern. A man who has no business being in the Oval Office.

Sorry. But you, like Donald Trump, can't blame the MSM for everything! -- If anything, he has earned all the contempt and scorn which he now faces, by putting it out there in the first place.
In fact, his entire campaign was run on hateful rhetoric and scathing stereotypes.
What goes around, comes around.

I used to read the New York Times and comfortingly thought that I was reading unbiased and thoroughly researched events. But with your current pieces on the Philippines, I would like to get more information from others as I believe your recent articles were very bad. There is that overnight journalist, who consorted with known goons in my city, and took them as reliable sources, condemning the President. Then, there was your op-ed piece by Mr. Syjuco, also very critical of President Duterte's leadership. Mr. Syjuco's parents, both of them, are being investigated now fow for graft and corruption. Could we have expected an "unbiased opinion?"
What a bunch of slimebags, throughout this sad epic, in NV, SV, and the Pentagon. Five young men from my tiny country high school died in this fiasco.
YAY! Let's have fifty different systems of health care so that we can see who wins the race to the bottom. And remember: drifting coal smog stops at state borders.
Perhaps the author didn't mention the absence of elections in North Vietnam because this article isn't about North Vietnam, nor is it about the differences between the North and the South.

I liked the factual history, but was unpersuaded by the conclusion of the essay.

The article ends by lamenting the failure of South Vietnam's political system to evolve in response to the demands placed upon it. However, that view focuses attention entirely upon the Vietnamese, as though Americans were not close at hand. A vast amount of graft and in-fighting was provoked among Vietnamese politicians and citizens by the sudden influx of American dollars. And with foreign advisers whispering in the ears of compliant Vietnamese warlords, civilian politicians never had a chance of succeeding.

The author also seems to forget how much war strains democratic institutions and practices, even in long-established democracies. Lincoln suspended habeas corpus during the US Civil War. More recently, wars have been the occasion for man other anti-democratic activities: secret NSA wiretaps, drone attacks, torture, intentional misrepresentations (Gulf of Tonkin, claims that Saddam possessed WMD's), Japanese citizens were held in camps during WW2, etc.

It appears to me that US policy makers were guilty of treating the Vietnamese people as a means toward an end -- the delay or defeat of global Communism. That points to a problem with American, not Vietnamese, democratic institutions. (That was what American protesters believed at the time, too.)

I was self-employed, forced into early retirement at the age of 56. Kept up the individual policy I'd had for many years, with the premiums going up by over $2,000 every year. So when I got cancer five years later, the costs were fully covered.

Those who are self-employed don't have company-backed plans, must pay for health insurance directly. The costs before ACA were often outrageously high.
You may want to take that back after the early am Trump tweets today...

Hahahahahahahaha!!!! Republicans!?!?!?!?! Courageous!?!?!? Hahahahahahahahahaha!!!!!! I can't get either my Republican Representative or my Republican Senator to even return my emails about health care or Trumps Russian adventures, never mind having the intestinal fortitude to actually show up for a "town hall" anywhere near our little mountain town!! As far as I can tell, they're in headlong flight from the people they were elected to represent into the arms of whoever paid for them to get elected! Courage!?!?!?! Don't tell me jokes like that this early. I'll choke on my coffee.

This is incredibly sad, it was not supposed to be this way, independence from the brutal North and subsequent self-rule, was supposed to bring peace and prosperity, especially with the oil resources.

They need more civil, but definitely not military, support from the west.

I respectfully disagree in one thing ( the evidence is undisputed). The word "brutal" should be used to describe the Dinka soldiers i.e. the soldiers of the government of South Sudan.In fact it is medieval barbarity & crimes against Humanity.
We should apologize to the people of Northern Sudan for demonizing them years ago , not knowing what would happen in the future Republic of South Sudan. Also we should bring the leaders of South Sudan to a court for crimes against Humanity.
And what form should that civil support take? And why from the 'west'?
First they came for the unions. Then they came for the ACA. Then they came for...

The GOP is quietly arguing that we should repeal the ACA and 'give power back to the states'. In other words, we should go back to the way it was prior to The ACA. This is an argument for Socialism.,,,stay with me.

Prior to the ACA, 30 mm Americans did not have healthcare. So, they would simply go to the ER to get their treatment (by law, hospitals must treat everyone). So, who paid for this inefficient, expensive visit? Taxpayers. It was part of your Medicare tax. Today, under the ACA, Americans must take some responsibility and buy their own healthcare or face a penalty...that is capitalism folks. Americans have always been proud of their culture--independence, self sufficient, competitive and capitalist.

Then why does the GOP want to go back to a system of Socialized medicine where the taxpayers simply pay for coverage of uninsured...in the ER?
